posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91170593
>It isn't power saving when you have a so called 15w or 25w chip that needs to pull 40w to deliver peak performance
No, that's a concept known as race to idle. The idea being that you'll usually only need peak performance for a short time, so you design the cooler around that. Yes, it can be shitty, but there is a method to the madness. And the TDP doesn't relate to the power draw or heat output of the chip, only the capacity of the recommended cooler for it.

That's only because every other ARM implementation sucks dick compared to the M series. Qualcomm is trying to change that, but we don't know yet how successful they're going to be.

>apple makes the only semi-serious ARM laptop and it's not selling in huge numbers
It's selling in huge numbers compared to previous Macbooks. You can see that on this board, even. There's actual serious discussion about the merits of Apple's new machines whereas the old ones with Intel processors were rightly identified as not very good. The entire industry is also moving pretty rapidly to improve ARM support; Microsoft has a version of Windows available with an ARM translation layer that's honestly not too bad and Linus Torvalds is now using an M series machine for moving ARM development for the Linux kernel forward. As mentioned, Qualcomm is working on an M series competitor. /g/ has a bunch of luddites, but the writing is on the wall. I can't say what kind of penetration ARM will reach, but the industry is taking it very seriously.

>Arm machines will all be special snowflakes needing a manufacturer supplied OS like phones do
Linux runs on ARM and has for a very long time, retard. I currently use a Debian-based OS (Armbian) and an Arch-based OS (PiKVM) on ARM machines. The Raspberry Pi CM series only has to get a little more powerful to be a serious contender for use as a daily driver for most people.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91173651
here is the latest thing i genned while fucking around modifyign the prompt a bit and making a 3x3 grid to see what sort of output i would get. Basically, if you're going from a blank slate it's quite a bit of work, but I have my default settings all set for steps/cfg/sampler/etc and i also always drag an old image into the "png info" tab and copy the prompt back into my txt2img and work from there to modify it, so i have a sort of baseline set, meaning yes in theory i get something great spat out immediately (at least IMO) but it is based on prior prompting, but you can also just copy another anon's prompt and work sideways from that. And yes, model is the ~4GB file such as "Stable Diffusion 1.5" or "Waifu Diffusion 1.3" or "Anything v3" or "AOM2" or whatever. The major difference is that most of the custom ones we use here are trained off booru datasets which means you can enter a booru tag in the prompt like "cleavage" or "naughty face" and while the base SD model has a basic idea of what these means, booru models have an EXTREMELY high attention high understanding of how these terms relate to an image through their ridiculously clean dataset used for the finetune, so you can get extremely specific in your desires through txt2img. booru tag autocomplete extension is a must have, and a tab open on danbooru to enter a tag like "smug" so you can see what tags usually co-exist with it and either ban or emphasise them

>>91174968
you need to write a Character Upload Protocol. So what that is is a protocol that further defines the small factors of the picture. You then need to explicity include your CUP in the prompt. There is a syntax that has to be followed as each CUP has to be numerically delimited and you can only use one CUP per prompt at the moment so the definition for both characters has to be in the one CUP. so your prompt would be something like 2 girls 1CUP.

happy to help.

posts.com:
>>91175306
as far as saving stuff goes there's the "styles" feature which lets you store prompts for later use using the dropdown on the right of the UI and the two last little icons under the 'generate' button.. but i find it very clunky to use and i'd rather just use a text doc lol.
in reality what i do these days is make heavy use of the 'png info' tab by dragging old generations into the control on that tab and hitting 'send to txt2img' and then building off it from there

in terms of actual generation parameters you can modify the default values a new tab will start up with by editing the "ui-config.json" file if you know which ones you really like to use. for instance mine starts up with DPM++ 2M Karras at 24 steps which is pretty standard/basic stuff. but using the pnginfo -> send to txt2img route actually sets those values too so it's not a big deal

re: repository of prompts, you can scroll through https://rentry.org/54d9o or search the archive for https://desuarchive.org/g/search/text/masterpiece%20quality/ or https://desuarchive.org/g/search/text/files.catbox%20png/

keep in mind the pnginfo tab relies on metadata to restore the prompt which 4chan strips out of files, so pictures downloaded from here won't let you pnginfo them, which is why people share images on catbox instead when passing prompts around

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
It's been a while since I wrote any C++ and this is my first post in this pit of depravitity. Apologies for syntax/formatting errors.

I think most employers and open source projects would prefer the second code (call it "standard code") to the first (call it "your code").

First, your code's explicit for loop doesn't handle the case where there are no positive integers in the array. You would need a handler which would add lines and complexity. The standard code would return an iterator to the final element, which may not be what you want but is at least defined. This may sound like pedantry but a lot of coding is just trying to cover all the things that could go wrong.

Second, many coders would claim that the standard code is more "readable". Let me try to break down what that means. When I read the standard code I think:
"Definition of is_positive. Sure. Ok. Maybe that will be useful in second"
"Ah. My old friend find_if. Being passed a begin and an end. That checks out. Oh. And also is_positive. Better go back and read that again. Ok. Sure. We're finding the first positive element. And I think we have guarantees about how long that will take. I could check the documentation but I'm sure it's all fine"

When I read your code I think:
"Ah. My old friend the for loop. Could be doing any number of insanely complicated things. Better have a deep look. Ok. The header part seems simple enough, just starting at zero and adding one until you get to the end. Maybe this for loop does something to each element of the array. Better check the body. Nope. I guess it is looking for positive elements. In which case it stops. So my previous assumption that we were going to do something to or look at each element of an array was wrong. We might break early. Does that matter? ... No. That seems fine. Unless we don't find any positive elements. Must be some code around here that handles that case."

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The point is that find_if does one thing that I'm probably already familiar with. Whereas a for-loop, especially a for-loop that terminates early, might do all kinds of strange things. I really need to take a detailed look and think about what it is doing.

The standard code would also be easier to understand in most other languages. In Javascript it might read something like:
return data.find(x => x > 0);
which is clearer than the C++ syntax in my view -- mostly because we have arrows that allow us to define the predicate function inline and avoid having to think of, and remember, a name for it.

Fundamentally, your code is imperative and concrete while the standard code is declarative and abstract. I concede that people can, and do, over use abstraction and declarative code. It's a phase I went through. Maybe it is a phase you need to go through to come out the other side writing clean code.

I'm going to end with some highly controversial advice: learn some Haskell (or Purescript or Elm). You don't have to write any real code in it but it will make this more abstract style of higher order functions familiar and maybe you'll even start to like it. Btw, in Haskell the code becomes:
find (> 0) data

List your websites as job experience. Post in your summary that you are looking for whatever position.
"I am open to junior web developer roles using react, typescript, javascript, node."

Then go on a connect spree. Look at the linkedin jobs section and find companies with openings, then search the companies and click on 'people' to find out who works there. Connect with two developers from each place and send a message in the connect request about how you really like what the company is doing and were wondering if they were hiring and, if so, who you should connect with.

Don't even necessarily apply for just junior roles since they don't really exist anymore.
By the way, this is a cheat code. If you just do the one-click apply you'll never, ever get a job. If you have a degree then find tech recruiters in your area. They are everywhere. Stay off of Dice or indians will spam your email and phone from here to eternity, trust me on that.

posts.com: The idea of single page applications is to have a div id="app" shell element on your page, with a script tag pointing towards your application JS. Your application JS will then render out your whole site on the client in to that shell using a UI library like React, and further interactions in the application will render out different stuff. When it comes to routing, all it really involves is the window.history JavaScript API to be able to render out what's supposed to be on the page.

  }

>>91175688
>fI think you're missing the point of React. React is supposed to render out your UI as a reflection of your current state. You don't seem to be using any state in your app, and are just calling "forceUpdate" to try to force a re-render of your application.
I thought it was strange as well, but this page says otherwise https://blog.logrocket.com/how-when-to-force-react-component-re-render/

It gives this example code, is that bad code as well?
import React from "react";

export default function App() {
 const [, updateState] = React.useState();
 const forceUpdate = React.useCallback(() => updateState({}), []);

 console.log("rendering...");

 return (
   <div className="App">
     <h1>Time to force some updates</h1>
     <button onClick={forceUpdate}>Force re-render</button>
   </div>
 );
}

The tax situation isn't universal though, it's personal. If you have investments that make money, you might owe more taxes out of your salary. If you pay a mortgage, you might get a deduction and pay less taxes. If you're married and you file jointly, your spouse's income will affect your tax rate. You're probably young, but your tax situation will probably get more complicated as you get older. It's essentially impossible for a company to factor all of those possibilities into some kind of average that would make sense for a majority of people.

The problem is you're asserting your opinion ("they are not paying $100k for a $100k salary") as fact when it's not. It's not a conspiracy, it's just a convention.
Also...
>they advertise as six figures before taxes, they will treat you as if they're paying six figures.
They ARE paying six figures. Every year you work a $100k salary, that company HAS paid out $100k. It just didn't all get to you, because you have to pay taxes (which they withheld for you). The company still paid $100k. That's why it still logically makes sense to say "a company pays me $100k" even if I don't get to keep all $100k... because they are paying that much, even if you personally disagree with that phrasing/terminology.

>Is "developers need local admin" such a controversial statement?
Ideally no-one should always be logged into their daily system with local admin credentials, not even IT.

The solution we use is for users who regularly need local admin, we require Duo MFA for login and elevation, and certificate-based app whitelisting so they can install programs from authorized vendors but not random programs.

>That is insane, here is a list of 50 tools
This is actually a very good reason to *not* give devs local admin. I've seen too many times where an entire project's dev/build process is reliant on heavily customized developer environments where they haven't documented anything.

If they need 50 tools to get a project running and they think it's too difficult to ask for them to be installed, there's no way they're documenting them anywhere else.

The most important things for security seem to be:

>>91153613
Yes, a Samsung S70A
Not the fanciest monitor but I like it, lots of screen space
The 16gb a770 is getting better, at least for what I play and do with it, most of my game library now runs fine after a few driver updates since I got it. The only remaining issues I have with it are
>really old games like UT99 have odd bugs like super fast game speed or strange resolution caps
>gta v super soft grass kills performance and MSAA cuts framerate in half
>halo MCC, the remastered version of halo 2 brings the card to its knees in 4K but it’s the only game in the collection to do that
>some weird lighting effects like molotovs in Insurgency are black
>many older but not super old titles that do hardware probes have no god damn idea how much video memory the card has and just read 1gb
They’ll use more than 1gb but I found in SecondLife for example, the 1gb read limit means you can only have 768mb of allocated vram for textures, so even if the game will use more than 1gb of vram by flagging to ignore hardware limits, it will still only let 768mb be used for textures
And SecondLife is a shitshow with textures since it’s all unoptimized user made content with assloads of 4k textures on every tiny object.

>>91172724
x^2 + y^2 = R^2 is not useful for calculating (x, y) pairs as you'd have to first solve it for either x or y in which case you get either:
x = sqrt(R^2 - y^2)
y = sqrt(R^2 - x^2)
which immediately becomes problematic because it'll give you two y/x values for each value you input. (you could of course choose the one closer to the cursor) It also fails to work everywhere on screen. If you actually knew anything about anything you'd know that the proper way to do this is to calculate the angle between the intersection of a line from the cursor to the center of your orbit and the x-axis and then using:
x = x_center + R cos(angle)
y = y_center + R sin(angle)

>>91170042
Sounds like a potential CPU or RAM related stability issue. At the very least I've seen the symptoms you describe and they were caused by CPU/RAM instability but it's hard to tell. If it's very rare it's going to be hard to catch, borderline stability issues like that are hard to diagnose. You could try a few runs of memtest86 to see if that uncovers anything and some CPU stress tests, but again even if those don't reveal anything it's not a guarantee no problem exists if the problem only happens rarely. Since CPUs have gotten really fancy with boosting and power saving it's become very hard to diagnose stability issues, stress tests which just peg the CPU to 100% won't necessarily reveal issues that happen in other load scenarios so it's all kind of fucked.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91170914
It's 80% recruiter spam and 10% tryhards treating it like its Facebook. You have to accept that and ignore it.
Get people you know to "endorse" you for skills. Is that a bullshit racket? Yes. Just do it.
After a few years in a career, when you're looking for a job, the easiest/best way is to go through someone you know. Even if that "know" is like one message a year for 3 years, at any small or mid-sized company you bypass the resume pile if an existing employee recommends you (does not work for BigCo Inc). The autistic nerd in me HATES that but I have learned to accept it.

I just log in once every week or so and wish people a happy birthday or happy "work anniversary", or thank anyone who did the same for me. You would be surprised how often people respond like you made their day just because you remembered they exist. Most people are drifting through a desert with bags over our heads, and just telling them "Hi, I remember you" is enough for them to like you. If they like you, they will remember you next time they are hiring for X and you have skills in X.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
In order to be a good developer, you need a specific type of person who is curious and good at solving problems. If you have that spark, you are going to be miles ahead of developers who don't. This is what spawned things like the 10x developer, because unlike other more standardized industries, the different between them may be that big.

There have always been tourists. You would get like a third or half decent people, and a third of half worse but still somewhat bearable guys. Lately, though, tourists are legion. You get clueless women, people reconverting in their 40s, low tier inmigrants, and just plain old idiots attempting to get those "300k" salaries which fill the internet, but which are they actually quite rare to a specific region in the world. That means that there are now teams where a single person does 120% of the work, and I say 120% because usually the retarded devs are a net negative to output; and teams where no work is being done at all.

Bad companies don't know that, and are happy that they get so many devs. Good companies have a bit of a feeling about this, and they pay high salaries but only for seniors. So what I am seeing recently is a larger divide between the good and the bad. That is why some people are swarmed by recruiters and have a 100% success rate between starting a process and getting a good offer, and why others need to go through 30 interviews to get a low paying job.

No, what happens is that people apply for the first N job they can find, which means they're applying to the most visible N job which means that they're applying to jobs that have 5-digit numbers of applicants (even if they're sourcing local jobs specifically). If you only apply to the 33 most visible jobs and you're only an above-average candidate then there's still only like a 1/50 chance of outcompeting everyone else.

Just write your own script
Function download
{
    param($id, $folder)
    if(-Not(Test-Path -Path $folder)){
        New-Item -Path $folder -ItemType Directory
    }
    $path = Join-Path -Path $folder -ChildPath $id
    $url = "https://simp4.jpg.church/{0}" -f $id
    Invoke-WebRequest -Uri $url -OutFile $path
}

Function generate
{
    param($url, $folder)
    $page = Invoke-WebRequest $url
    $page.Images | Where-Object {($_.src -like "*simp4.jpg.church*")} | ForEach-Object {
        download $_.alt $folder
    }
}

function LoadLinks 
{
    param($filename)
    Get-Content $filename | ForEach-Object {
        $folder = $_.Split("/")[-1].Split(".")[0]
        generate $_ $folder
    }
}

LoadLinks .\links.txt

>>91112023
>>91112071
>>91112081
The problem with KDE is mainly the fact that there are no good Qt application styles for Linux that can achieve the spacing correctly (MS Windows 9x gets close but falls apart really easily if you look closely into it). The only way to get a good looking solution is if the Qt styles native to Windows were somehow ported to Linux which isn't happening without significant effort (take a look at https://store.kde.org/p/1100832/ for inspiration)

The other problems come down to the fact that KDE's plasmoids and applications like the system settings are designed with a modern approach, which would make them look out of place.
You might get more luck by using TDE instead of KDE if you want a Windows 2000 look on your system. Take a look at https://xpq4.sourceforge.io/

t. https://gitgud.io/wackyideas/aerothemeplasma

>desktop mics are far better
so wrong
as someone who is regularly in skype conversation of 5-12 people; everyone really hates the few who come in with mics like this. they pick up all kinds of external noise because they are designed to work from a distance.

enjoy listening to every mouse and keyboard click (because often the mic is right behind the keyboard, god forbid they have a mechanical one on top of it), every fart from a mosquito and the sound of a clock ticking. its infuriating to listen to for extended periods and we have basically forced them to stay muted to stay on the call. anyone who afks with a remotely loud mic gets booted.

desktop mics are NOT good outside of programs like ventrillo where you can say what you need to and wont have background noise for the 4 seconds that you're talking. the problem is a lot of gamers who use these programs are moving to skype because 1. it's free 2. far far far better sound quality and 3. no delay in voice. therefore you end up being in a persistent phone conversation and desktop mics suck for this really badly.

while i agree that dedicated headphones provide better quality, if you need and will use a mic everyday/game session: get a fucking headset and save other people the noise pollution.

and dont talk about that clip on mic bullshit. those are great for hearing the ear gouging noise they cause whenever the person adjusts their position in their chair and it moves around. not to mention the extra wire that can get tangled/be annoying and the possibility of it falling off it you stress the cable at all because the clip often will just slide off your clothes

headset #1, get over it

posts.sub: /iemg/ & /pmpg/ - In-Ear Monitor & Portable Music Player General
posts.com:
New Year new edition

How to request advice:
>Budget
>Kind (in-ear or earbuds)
>Intended use
>Sound signature (or genres you like)
>Past gear and your thoughts on them

FAQs:
>Do I need a DAC/dongle?
Only if your source: lacks a headphone jack, has high noise/distortion (common on PC), or lacks power, i.e. your IEMs don't get loud enough
>Should I buy FiiO/CCA/KZ?
No. Despite their previous popularity, in 2023 these companies do not make competitive IEMs or DACs
>Where do I buy IEMs?
Amazon, Aliexpress, Linsoul, HiFiGo, Shenzenaudio

Guide to IEMs:
https://hackmd.io/@AyPeeEye/S1sNUVosu
*WIP New Guide to IEMs:
https://rentry.org/c8gqc

#Budget IEMs that are worn wire-over-ear with detachable cable:
• 7Hz Salnotes Zero (bright neutral) - $20
• QKZ x HBB (very bassy) - $20
• Tangzu Wan'er S.G (mild V) - $20
• Truthear Hola (bassy neutral) - $20

#Sweetspot IEMs with better build, accessories, and sound:
• Tinhifi C2 (bright neutral) - $30
• Tinhifi C3 (Harman) - $50
• TKZK Ouranos (mild U) - $55
• Moondrop Aria Snow Edition (warm neutral) - $80
• Tripowin x HBB Olina SE (bright neutral) - $100

DACs and USB dongles:
• US market Apple Dongle - $10
• VE Abigail bundle w/ Monk Plus earbuds - $15
• Moondrop Dawn (3.5 or 4.4) - $70
• Topping DX1 (dual 3.5 and 6.35 + hardware volume) - $100
• Qudelix 5K (dual 3.5 and 2.5 + Bluetooth) - $110

DAPs/PMPs and guide:
• Shanling M0 Pro - $130
• HiBy R3 Pro Saber 2022 - $210
• Sony NW-A55 + MrWalkman firmware - ~$200 used
https://azalush5.hatenablog.com/entry/2022/01/dap-comparison-2022-01

Bluetooth (TWS) and guide:
• Samsung Galaxy Buds Pro 2 - $230
• Apple AirPods Pro 2 - $250
https://scarbir.com/truewireless

import threadpool, os

var count: int
var prevCount: int

proc incrementCount() {.thread.} =
  while true:

proc printCount() {.thread.} =
  while true:
    var delta = count - prevCount
    prevCount = count

    sleep(200)

spawn printCount()

import threadpool, os, std/locks

var
  count:int
  L: Lock

proc incrementCount() {.thread.} =
  while true:
    acquire(L)
    inc(count)
    release(L)

proc printCount() {.thread.} =
  while true:
    stdout.write("\r" & $count)
    sleep(200)

initLock(L)
spawn printCount()
for i in 0..16:
  spawn incrementCount()
sync()

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91160668
>I ordered a 64GB USB stick for like $2.50
Where?
Can you link us the webpage you ordered it from?
>It's not some Chinese brand
I doubt it.
>apparently the write speeds are only around 10mb/s
This is pretty normal for cheap drives.
>Is it worth keeping a stick that slow
Not if you intend to "use" it for transferring data. Too slow. Too many better options.
As a bootable device for holding windows installation media or something, write speed doesn't matter, so it can serve well as that.
>maybe to run live Linux off or something.
Crazy slow flash drives are shit for that, the 10MB/s is slow but if the reads are fine that can work. It's probably not worth your time though.

For comparison you can buy a 64GB Samsung for $12 which will read out at 300MB/s and write at 35MB/s.
https://www.amazon.com/Samsung-MUF-64AB-AM-Plus-64GB/dp/B07D7P4SY4/

Your biggest concern is scammers.
What scammers do is take flash drive internals, modify their firmware, have a 1GB drive report its capacity as whatever, and put that in new plastic and sell it to you.
You'll think it's good until you go to retrieve data from it later. They write in a loop and overwrite old data causing guaranteed data loss.

If you want to keep your drive for whatever reason do the following, or something else approved by reddit at the least.
#1 - Run h2testw.exe write+verify test on the drive.
This writes data then reads it all back. If it can't read it back, it means the drive is counterfeit. Ignore any ~1MB warning, that's because of partitioning/etc getting in the way it will still test all allocated blocks used.
#2 - Run badblocks in Linux.
Open terminal and type
sudo badblocks -wsv /dev/YourStorageDeviceHere
This will erase the entire drive then write four patterns to the whole device and read them back.
If you get any errors, it's junk.
#3 - Write ~64GB of data to it (consider an encrypted .VHD) then read it back and check the hash value. If it's different, your drive is trash.

How exactly are you using the SSD?

This is Windows at its finest.
I have the same issue with every single one of my flash drives that are formatted with NTFS plugging it in to different versions of Windows.

The problem is NTFS is a journaling filesystem and it fucks with metadata every time it's plugged in, formatting external drives to exFAT solves this issue since it's a more compatible filesystem that doesn't let Windows do it's retard shit.

If your SSD keeps saying there's errors and to scan the drive when it's plugged in without it ever being plugged into another PC (or another OS install, dual booting, etc, or VMS) there might be a problem.

posts.com: How can an OS tell what filesystem a given storage device uses? Are there magic numbers involved like with files?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91167515
yes

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91167515
Every single modern drive is a miniature all-in-one computer these days. Your computer doesn't read drives. It simply listens to the thing LARPing as a drive.

When reading the first few LBAs of a drive, information regarding the partition/filesystems will be read.
If nothing exists, it will ask you to initialize it or create/format a partition for use.
If you're encrypting it it'll show up as a RAW partition but the base information about a partition existing will be in plaintext.

Only a few bits need to be stored to describe how the drive is configured. No real "user data" ever gets written to these sections and that's why recovering data about lost/reformatted partitions is possible.


Unfortunately this means you can't really do specific things with the hardware at a low level anymore but it also means your OS doesn't have to personally worry about every little tiny operation a drive has to deal with.

posts.com: /g/entlemen, last year I remember there was some shit about chrome fucking up AD blocking starting this year, what happened to that? Been using chrome and my adblocking never broke.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91169317
They moved the deadline: https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/mv3/mv2-sunset/

The way it will work is like this: On Chrome you will need to use Google's ad blocking engine. The extensions are not allowed to directly interfere with what is being downloaded.
The extensions will instead register a filter list to Chrome.

For basic blocking that's fine. You can't even see what was being blocked, though - that's all done internally. And the blocking will always be limited to what Chrome provides.
This is what they provide as a replacement (since extensions will not be able to modify or block any requests themselves): https://developer.chrome.com/docs/extensions/reference/declarativeNetRequest/

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91173971
The fat PS2 is the best PS2 because you can modify the HDD/Network adapter to accept up to a 2TB SATA drive. Its firmware is old enough that soft mods like FreeMCBoot work, so you can install your library on the 2TB drive and play everything off the HDD. Since you don't need the optical drive for this, you can pick up a broken fat PS2 that doesn't read disks to use as the base system very cheap.

However, since the PS2 is past its 20th anniversary, its price has gone up now that it's considered "retro". Complete systems (console, connectors, controllers) used to run $40 or so but now go for over $100 for good examples.

The PS2 was an example of a console that did everything right and the sales show this: to date, it is still the best selling console of all time.

Anyone in this thread remember "cable rounding?" posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
These days the CPU makers beat their chest about a 10-20% generational improvement every two years.
In the 90's up through 2001 or 2002, the generational difference was STARK. Every generation of CPU was 50-100% faster than the previous, and so if you got a new computer after 3-4 years you had this multi-month honeymoon period where you thought "HOLY SHIT" every time you did ANYTHING because it was literally two, three or four times as fast as your previous machine. It wore off over months, but this happened with multiple computers that you owned, in a row. It is why a lot of people got jaded in the late 00's, bought upgrades less often, because it just didn't feel as meaningful. Because it wasn't.

Now let's talk monitors. They are the opposite: you put up with them, but compared to the late 2010's, they advanced slowly. You started getting "flat screen" CRTs in the late 90's and early 00's, but LCDs didn't become the norm for a new system until... 2003-2005 depending on price point? Even then most people who had a computer were satisfied with it, and didn't get a new one right away. CRTs are cool in their own way, but I'm happy to never have to fucking carry one across town, up and down stairs, ever again, just to play a game with my friends. They took up so much desk space it was unholy.

Why would you carry a bigass CRT across town? Because not everyone could afford the same internet speed, or have anything more than DIALUP, on a single phone line, and if someone else needed to make a phone call, you had to log off randomly. People talk about how awesome weekend-long LAN Parties were because, well, they were awesome. But also you HAD to feel proud about anything that required a dozen people to each move a fucking tower and a fucking monitor all into one place.

>>91166710
Now let's talk about physical media.
There was a weird period where we went from buying software on literally 10+ floppy disks (for the largest programs) to a single CD. Assuming you had a CD-ROM drive. That felt magical. Even then, CDs still represented a level of annoyance, because nobody's hard drives were large enough to load an ENTIRE game onto them. You might have 260MB of game assets on a CD but your entire hard drive was 1GB, if you were LUCKY. You "installed" a game, but that was just the executables and some base assets. You still had to have the CD in the machine to run the game, because no one would ever imagine you would "install" the entire game to your main storage. The few people who had a second hard drive as a "(D:)" drive or "(E:)" drive were so rare that companies didn't even give you the option of putting the game on that disk: You HAD to have the CD in a disk drive to play it.

So what if you swapped between playing 4-5 games regularly?
Well if you were that one lucky sonnovabitch whose dad also played PC games, you had a tower with 3, 4 or 5 CD drives in it! Why? Because then the most commonly played games would already have their CD loaded, and you didn't have to go find it, open the drive, swap it out, etc.

Most of us just had a big pile of stacked CD "jewel cases" sitting somewhere in the area of the gaming PC. Smart people had a little CD organizer, like it was a piece of furniture. Oh, and games came in Music CD-sized square cases, rather than DVD-sized rectangular ones.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91166744
Now scarcity. The biggest difference after 2010 we crossed a line from "one devices serves multiple people" to "most people have multiple devices". Before 2005 or so, most people didn't have a computer. In the 90's, people who did probably shared it with their entire family, or at least one other family member (if you were rich: parent had a work computer, kids had a shared computer). What if it was 1995, and you wanted to play MYST, but your older sibling had to type up an essay? You waited. What if you were playing MYST and you were really into it... well you probably had some arrangement where you swapped off with your sibling, your friend who was visiting, or whoever, so that you played for an hour while they watched, and then they played for an hour while you watched.

That's right. You sat next to them, or stood behind them, and paid rapt attention as they played the game. If you were collaborating on one save file, you had to deal with them making dumbass decisions you disagreed with. The alternative was having your own save and so then you swapped between playing content you ALREADY SAW THEM PLAY or vice versa. Or to avoid spoilers you would fuck off somewhere else and... be bored or something. But let's be honest: glowing screens are cool so you watched them and heckled them when they fucked up.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91167031
WiFi didn't exist, or where it did, it was a joke in both speed and reliability until the early 00's. That was fine because the idea that you could just "be online", any time at all, was not an expectation. Laptops were also rare, and might not even have Wireless LAN (to get network connections you plugged into a docking station). Since devices weren't mobile so you weren't moving a computer with you from one room to another, or one place to another. Having a copper wire run over to the machine was no burden, and when it comes down to it, copper wires are pretty good at what they do.
Lucent or AT&T or someone like that had some WiFi-esque tech in the mid-90's but only a few businesses even used it. No one's home had those systems because home PCs weren't sold with them, and I'm not even sure if they came as PCI cards (not PCIe: original PCI).

Speaking of PCI, if you were a baller and had a dedicated "Graphics Card" back in the day, you plugged it into a dedicated graphics slot on the motherboard known as "AGP", because PCIe didn't exist and normal PCI was insufficient. The shape and size of an AGP slot was different, and most often colored brown.

posts.com: My dad bought me PC parts for Xmas when I was 13, he showed me how to assemble it but beyond that it was completely mine. I would reinstall Windows several times a year after attempting to pirate stuff (think warez sites). For whatever reason I recall "Dr Watson's post mortem debugger" killing Windows most often. It would run a timer before it forcibly shut down the computer, maybe 30 seconds. Until we got DSL, our family used dialup but my dad refused to buy a second phone line. This resulted in my sister needing to call home (no cell phones) and getting a busy signal because I wanted to roleplay in AOL chat rooms. Sometimes she would be on the phone when I tried to use dialup, and her screaming voice would actually come out of the modem speaker. I have no regrets, she was a horrible sibling.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91175116
>I wonder if websites appeared as silly as NFT's did now.
I feel like there was a little more credulity. People were just as cynical as i any era in general, but less cynical about the internet, because it seemed legitimately new.
As >>91175189 said there were definitely individual companies who unironically had pitches that were "We lose money on every sale, but we make it up in volume!"
Many, many mainstream middle-class investors lost money in the dot com bust. A different kind of investor than the crypto/web3/NFT investor in some ways, but at least some similarity existed.

The difference was that the overall idea underpinning it wound up being very central to our lives, and very valuable, in the long run. That "long run" took a decade, so by that measure, it is yet to be seen if "blockchain" or "web3" is equally valuable. I don't think so, but hey, I might just be that guy in 2002 saying "Yeah that web thing was cool, but it's never going to be as big as Television."

When I open certain applications that have sound output in my Arch VM (pipewire(-alsa|-pulse)on both host and guest) I see in my host's pavucontrol that the guest sound output mutes itself and sets its volume to 0%. If I unmute and raise the volume, but reopen the application, it mutes itself on the host again.
What can I do to have it always at 100%?
Here's how I specify the audio for my QEMU VM:
        -device intel-hda \
        -device hda-micro \
        -audiodev pa,id=snd0 \

So in pavucontrol it shows as "VM name: snd0."

How can I make this better?
#!/bin/bash

# Convert lossless files to FLAC and delete originals
# Usage: ./toflac.sh "/path/to/dir" [opts]
# Options: dry - will do a dry run

dir="$1"
fn=0
fc=0

for f in $dir
do
  if [[ -f "$f" ]] && [[ "$f" == *.wav || "$f" == *.aiff || "$f" == *.aif ]]; then
    ((fn++))
  fi
done

echo $fn files total
if [[ $fn -gt 0 ]]; then echo "Encoding files..."; fi

for f in $dir
do
  if [[ -f "$f" ]] && [[ "$f" == *.wav || "$f" == *.aiff || "$f" == *.aif ]]; then
    if [[ $2 == "dry" ]]; then
      ffmpeg -y -hide_banner -loglevel error -i "$f" -c:a flac -compression_level 8 -f null -
    else
      ffmpeg -y -hide_banner -loglevel error -i "$f" -c:a flac -compression_level 8 "${f%.*}.flac"
    fi
    ((fc++))
    echo "Completed: $fc / $fn ($f)"
    if [[ -f "${f%.*}.flac" ]] && [[ $2 != "dry" ]]; then
      #remove original file
      rm -f "$f"
    fi
  fi
done

Today, while setting up the new OS and writing some data over, my device remounted read-only out of nowhere. From `dmesg` I pulled the following:
BTRFS critical (device sdc4): corrupt leaf: root=18446744073709551610 block=914554880 slot=262, bad key order, prev (9008 96 14) current (9008 96 14)

Anon, can you explain the relationship between RHEL, CentOS, and Fedora?

RHEL is a paid enterprise Linux distro. A stable and reliable distro with tech support etc. Its source code is GPLd.
Fedora is an upstream of RHEL. It's less stable but it costs you no money. Fedora users are basically guinea pigs of RHEL.
CentOS used to be a free (!) bug-for-bug copy of RHEL. It's allowed to copy RHEL because of GPL license.
CentOS used to have the stability of an enterprise Linux but at no cost for the end user.

Now it's seems like Fedora is a bleeding edge testing distro. It's an upstream distro in Red Hat ecosystem.
CentOS is being replaced with Cent OS Stream. CentOS Stream is is more stable than Fedora but also a testing distro. So, it's a midstream.
RHEL is the most reliable and stable. Only after packages were tested in Fedora and then in CentOS Steam do they go to RHEL.
RHEL is a downstream.

So, if you want to use a Red Hat distro not paying money, you're basically forced to be a bug tester.

It seems like Rocky Linux is a bug-for-bug RHEL now.
Did I get everything right?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91172679
RHEL is the daddy of them all. Enterprise Linux for businesses which you need a license to use.
Fedora is the freee upstream consumer version of RHEL for desktops.
CentOS was a binary-compatible clone of RHEL that didn't require a license, which has now been replaced by Rocky Linux and Alma Linux.

you are iterating through files twice
quote your variables (unless in [[, it doesn't matter there)
bash has more legible syntax for integers: (( fn > 0 )) (or just (( fn )), since 0 fails)
more of a preference, but better to use an array, like files=("${dir:?}/"*) (${var:?} fails if $var is empty/not set) and then iterate over it: for f in "${files[@]}"; do ...
you can check the extension with [[ ${f##*.} =~ (wav|aiff?) ]]

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91172734
I understand what binary compatibility means.
Alma and Rocky maintainers don't compile stuff themselves, they copy binaries of RHEL instead.
So, if RHEL injects some malicious functionality to their system (spyware and other good stuff like that), Rocky and Alma can't do anything about it.
The same concern can be applied to any binary distro. There's always a chance that your distro maintainers do nasty stuff. Even if they only ship FOSS software. But what can you do? In this regard, it's the same as using Windows or Mac. Trust your distro maintainers or use Gentoo or better LFS.
But it's an overkill for many people. Because nasty things can be done on a hardware. We all rely on AMD, GeForce, and Intel anyway.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Code design question.

You have a class with a single method that transforms some inputs into an output:
interface Transformer {
  Output transform(A a, B b, C c);
}

interface CGetter {
  C get(B b, D d);
}


Should callers of transform be responsible for doing this:
C c = cGetter.get(b, d);
if (c == null) {
 // handle
}
handle(transformer.transform(a, b, c))


Or should transform take 'D' instead like this:
Output transform(A a, B b, D d) {
  C c = cGetter.get(d);
  if (c == null) {
    return null;
  }
  ...
}


Pros/cons of the transformer checking:
+ Don't need to duplicate the check for all callers. If you also wanted to log missing inputs, this is also simpler as it's in one place.
- Passing dependencies of dependencies (transform doesn't need D, it needs C) seems like a mistake. makes testing more complicated as you need to mock cGetter, etc

What would be the simplest and fastest way to map between 2 coordinate systems like this? For each black point I need to find a floating point position within the red grid slots. The red grid may be rotated up to 90 degrees and scaled separately in X and Y to any arbitrary sizes.

It's similar(?) to bilinear texture rendering, except:
1. the top left of both grids are always in the same position
2. red grid can only be rotated up to 90 degrees into either direction
3. I also need negative positions, so in pic related the bottom left of black grid needs to map to the correct red grid values (with negative x)

My intuition tells me that you can do it with a simple trig calculation but my brain is blanking out when I try to think about it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91169834
You can do this with a matrix multiply. If you're only rotating and scaling you only need a 2x2 matrix, otherwise you'd use a 3x3 to add translation. You create a rotation matrix, scale matrix, multiply them, then multiply that with your X and Y coordinates.
Because the matrices are so small you can just expand everything out on paper and end up with the trig you wanted.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91169834
The both easiest and most effective way is to use matrices.
Your point's coords that you multiply with a 4x4 matrix.

Well, 4x4 for 3D points, as you are in 2D, only a 3x3 is needed.
Your points needs to be [[X,Y,0]]
Your matrix is, if I remember correctly, [[cos(a),-sin(a),translation_X], [sin(a), cos(a), translationY], [XScale, YScale,1]], and you get a 3x3 matrix, and you take the diagonal for you [X,Y,0] with your new points.

I know it sounds complicated, but using this method, you will be able to do rotations, translation and scaling all at the same time.
Plus, it's already highly used because the 3D version is used everywhere for, dhu, 3D.
By the way, you can use a 3D lib and just set Z to 0, it will work all the same.

Look up how transform matrices works, it's really easy.

As for matrices multiplications, basically:
[A            [ [ (A*C), (A*D) ]
 ,  x [C,D] =          ,
 B]             [ (B*C), (B*D) ] ]

A 2x1 matrix multiplied by a 1x2 gives a 2x2 matrix.

So, if you develop the previous matrices I gave you, you will find something like newX = ((oldX*cos(a))-(oldY*sin(a))) +offsetX
I don't remember by heart the scaling when you develop the matrices.

Tl,Dr:
Try transformation matrices, it's way easier than you thought.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91170192
Scaling is actually along the diagonal. Think of how each 1 in the identity matrix corresponds to one component in the vector. To scale that coordinate you just replace that 1 with some scaling factor.

If you do want translation you would augment the vectors to be (X, Y, 1). If you use (X, Y, 0) with the same matrix you get rotation and scale with no translation. This can be useful for transforming points and directions with a single matrix. Otherwise like I said here >>91170084 you can just skip that part and stick with 2x2.

Rgba8 get_color (int time, f32 x, f32 y) {
    f32 scalex = (sin(time*0.02) * 0.5 + 0.7) * 60;
    f32 scaley = (sin(time*0.01) * 0.5 + 0.7) * 30;
    f32 rotate = sin(time*0.03) * 0.2;
    
    // rotate
    f32 tx = x;
    f32 ty = y;
    x = tx * cos(rotate) + -ty * sin(rotate);
    y = tx * sin(rotate) +  ty * cos(rotate);
    
    // scale
    x /= scalex;
    y /= scaley;
    
    // position within a cell
    f32 subx = x - floor(x);
    f32 suby = y - floor(y);
    
    // visualize
    f32 val = max(subx, suby) * 255;
    f32 r = val * (x / 8);
    f32 g = val;
    f32 b = val * (y / 8);
    Rgba8 c = {
        .r = min(r, 255),
        .g = min(g, 255),
        .b = min(b, 255),
        .a = 255
    };
    return c;
}

static int t = 0;
t ++;

for (int y=0; y<200; y++) {
    for (int x=0; x<200; x++) {
        Rgba8 color = get_color(t, x, y);
        draw_pixel(x, y, color);
    }
}

posts.com:
While experimenting I just had a lovely realization. 
: foo a b do c long-phrase-uses-i d loop e ;

I initially thought you couldn't extract the middle phrase into its own word, since `i` relies on the rstack, but you can just fuck with the rstack directly!
: extracted r> long-phrase-uses-i >r ;
: foo a b do c extracted d loop e ;

This uses the datastack as a temporary store for `extracted`s return address, which we restore before it exits, essentially splicing any uses of `i` as though it were from the calling word.

Man, Forth is cool.

posts.com:
Users of all levels are welcome.
Share Windows tools, utilities, tips & tricks.

FAQ:
>How do I activate Windows?
https://github.com/massgravel/Microsoft-Activation-Scripts
HWID mimics upgrade activation to generate a permanent legitimate license. (works on non-VL editions only)

>>Which W10 version should I install?
>Home/Pro
Comes with bloatware apps (games, music, news, etc) and bloatware system apps
>Education/Workstation/Enterprise
Comes with bloatware system apps (weather, people, onedrive, teams, etc).
>LTSC (5 years support, VL/KMS only) / IoT LTSC (10 years support, HWID only)
Comes with Win32 system utils, no MS Store, no apps.
If you need MS Store, run this in cmd: wsreset -i
Install Xbox/Gamebar apps for feature parity with other editions.

>Do I even need IoT LTSC?
W10 Home/Pro/Edu/WS/Ent editions end support in 2025, LTSC in 2027, IoT LTSC in 2032.

>How do I activate Office?
https://github.com/abbodi1406/KMS_VL_ALL_AIO/releases
Emulates a KMS server, not ideal as KMS trips AV sometimes and deactivates. Alternatively, use MSOffice through your browser since it's free.
Or you can try OnlyOffice/LibreOffice and set it to save as MSOffice file formats.

>Where can I get Windows/Office ISOs?
https://massgrave.dev/genuine-installation-media.html
Other sources:
https://pastebin.com/p6b3N9w2

>Should I debloat or Optimize-Offline?
If you need to ask, then no. You WILL break something.
If you know what you're doing:
https://pastebin.com/S5VKBirt

>Windows/Office install guide
https://rentry.org/windowsinstallguide

>Portable programs & partitioning for reinstall-proofing
https://pastebin.com/Zh7WSbJ2

>Useful programs for a new install
https://pastebin.com/hN8nnwns

>Make 4chan/fwt easier to browse
https://www.4chan-x.net

>I miss Windows##
OpenShell/RetroBar/WinClassic/StartIsBack

>Is W11 good?
No.

>i don't own X item in image

All of these posters missed the point. There is a flaw in believing that certain products are signals to others about your intelligence, personality, and societal value. The archetype "Bugman" is the person who has fully absorbed this belief into their unconscious mind - they struggle to confront the idea. Like you, /g/tard, trying to find some obscure Windows system operation in Task Manager.
The problem is in believing the signal is the thing itself. A fountain pen means I am eloquent. A nice guitar means I am musical, a girlfriend means I am charming.
I encourage you, Anons, in the week ahead please ask yourself some questions and learn more about who you are:
>how does owning object X make me *feel* about myself?
>do I like feeling that way?
>what does it mean TO ME to *be* that, not just to *feel* it?
To give some nuance to the last question: when we are cold and it is cold in the environment, we say "I am cold." But when we are cold in a warm room, we say "I feel cold." Do you understand the difference?

>>91158987
GPT3 or any LLM (Large Language Model) only does transformations on text based on statistical patterns, with billions of parameters trained on huge amounts of text, the importance of these is to have a basis for other Natural Language Processing tasks, creating text is just a sample of its capabilities, AGI is the ability to replicate human intelligence in an artificial way.

Any idea thought by a human or any act would be able to be replicated, such as scientific discoveries or the creation of technology or entertainment, even improve itself or create new and better versions.

In this case LLMs only display coherent text or text queries learned from text written by dozens of millions of humans on the internet.

The text is just a representation of things that are real or human experiences, LLMs can play with the text but consider the map to be the territory, in this sense LLMs understand nothing, they know nothing, they just play with words in texts that entertain humans.

AGI, would create the cure for all diseases, immortality, intergalactic travel and all kinds of science and technology, is what the singularity theorists preach.
Superficial artificial intelligence will enclose the human being in a bubble of entertainment and pleasures where he will always have something to look at, something to read or something to laugh about.

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Map%E2%80%93territory_relation

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91161431
The possibility space of the text is exponential (number of words to use) raised to (number of words in the text), LLMs use learning writing patterns, the use and relationship of words to each other, to cope with an exponential problem, creating small local sentences that are very similar and connect to each other, giving the appearance of coherent text but which has no overall coherence or consistency with the real world, this is not a path to AGI, trying to fix these problems is pointless, LLMs just generate huge amounts of text that may look good at first glance to humans, but not to reality.

The possibility of an LLM writing a cure for cancer is less than finding a specific hydrogen atom in the universe.

>>91159185
Don't speak as if you know about neurology.
The same bulk area manages visual and aural tasks.
If you focus too much on trying to hear something, your visual awareness diminishes considerably. Magicians use this all the time.
Likewise, vice versa, if you focus so intensely on a visual task, you can become deaf to lots of aural input.
It's the exact same area that get's used in vision, hearing and echo-location. The same 3D awareness processing is done in that one region. A large region at that, it's one of the more power hungry areas of the brain.
This is old news as well.
https://hearingreview.com/inside-hearing/research/new-research-shows-visual-cortex-processes-auditory-information
It's not so much the "visual cortex", it's more the spatial cortex to be exact - it places the world around us. (I have no doubt touch also plays a role there as well, but I don't think anyone has looked in to that yet)

>>91143692
rythm is nice, good energy
but too crowded / busy and fast in relation to what it offers in melody
I just listened to it and couldn't whistle it to you if I tried
in other words there is no 'suspension of disbelief' , I just picture your hands and on the keyboard and you arranging tracks in the daw.
The alternating phases and overall construction of the track is nice but there is nothing in melody.
The more energy and drama you reach for, the more catchy the notes needs to be. They are not so as a result your energetic and fast rythmes are tiresome and the track is forgettable.
I would go for slower and / more research to find impactful and catchy melodies. Also I would decrease the busyness to go for something more minimalist so I convey an emotion instead of a tedious and generic vidya type tune that get annoying very fast because it basically wants my attention with high energy but never deliver in being catchy or memorable.

All harmonic minors sound ugly when you play them as a scale or a melody because there's an augmented second interval between the 6th and 7th degrees of the scale.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Have you guys setup ThrottleStop on your intel-based Thinkpads? My T470 benefitted significantly by undervolting, here are the values I setup here, with lots of testing. The benefits are significant, the CPU and GPU can both boost to 100% frequency without triggering either thermal throttle or power throttle, it also allows adjusting the thermal limit of the laptop. Default is 75'c to keep the laptop quiet and cool regardless of load, but most other OEMs set 90-95'c, I increased mine to 85'c, which it only ever hits after a length GAEMAN session. Applying these undervolts reduced heat by about 10'c under load and added 1-2hrs to the battery life. Before adjusting these, the i5-6300u would throttle to ~2ghz under GPU load, but now stays boosted to the full 2.9ghz at all times without throttling.

I also registered it as a windows service with a utility called "NSSM", because I've noticed sometimes it crashes and disappears from systray when plugging and unplugging the laptop. This way it runs in the background and keeps it's settings applied without having any systray icon in every user account, and the service can be set to restart automatically if it crashes.

T480s has one soldered RAM as well as 1 slot afaik, if you buy one with 8gb RAM you should be able to buy a second 8gb stick to get - UNLESS it's one with 4gb soldered in and 4gb in the free slot, but generally if they're spec'd 8gb or less from lenovo there's an empty slot and no dual channel. T480 has 2 RAM slots with generally one filled by the factory. s models generally have internal batteries only and no removable while T480 has one removable one internal.

X1 Carbon 6th gen takes it one step further with only soldered RAM and no slots, so T480s is a half-way point to an X1 Carbon with some upgradability and some lost due to thinness.

Each step towards a thinner model also has less key travel I think. T480 = 2.0mm travel, T480s = 1.7mm travel, X1 Carbon (6th gen) 1.5mm travel, something like that. So fatter models have nicer feeling keyboards. Naturally, fatter models should deal with higher loads easier with the same CPU due to more cooling space.

idk what country youre from but i assume its eu wide now.
the situation used to be everything that was below 22 euros was exempt from import tax and fees.
new eu wide law is that everything you order outside the eu needs to be taxed (some webstores like ali already include this in the displayed price) but all items below 150 euros dont have any import fees.
in most cases this is actually cheaper and a better system compared to the previous if you buy electronics which are over 22 euros.

TLDR: new laws require you to pay tax on any item shipped from outside the eu but no import fees will be charged for items up to 150 euro which in most cases ends up being cheaper for the consumer if you order items that are 22 euros or more

>What's the worst that can happen with a shitty cable?
Higher resistance due to thin copper cables so slower charging because of losses. I'll be fine for data transfer or whatever. Some phones have problems with shit charging cables due to these losses. The longer the cable the higher the losses and 2 meters are considered "long" for low voltage power delivery, remember it's actually 4 meters of cable in total, there and back (positive and negative wire). Other than that you'll probably be fine.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91110128
I'm not the anon you were replying to by the way, I simply couldn't resist making the joke. But I do wear glasses myself for over 25 years now.

>anyway, how "safe" are those cleaners? a few threads ago some Anon said the cleaner broke his glasses
There are two potential and easily avoidable issues with using ultrasonic cleaners for glasses. The first is the risk of scratching up the lenses beyond repair. This happens the moment you have the cleaner running and allow the lenses to touch the walls of the cleaner, or when you have other loose items or hard debris in it. These scratches happen near instantly and pretty much can't be fixed. The second issue comes from using aggressive cleaning solutions which eat away at coatings, glues or acrylic frames. Mild hand soap is about as harsh you want to go for regular cleaning, diluted blue spirits is what opticians use but should never be used regulary as it will eat away at coatings. But all of this is assuming you're buying a proper ultrasonic cleaner, and not some bullshit Chinese plastic tub with a N64 rumble pack pressed against it.

Personally I just use tap water to rinse of dirt and a clean microfiber cloth for my daily cleaning. If that's not enough I'll use a Zeiss wet wipe or blue spirits diluted with demineralised water if things are really bad. I need new glasses every 2 to 3 years on average due to my still deteriorating eyesight and cleaning like has never caused me to scuff or scratch up my glasses. Don't overthink cleaning your shit, they're just glasses.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Fiftyseven ESIS model kit (€30)
As promised in >>91074157, a full review now that I've build the kit. For this build I used DSPIAE nippers, Revell needle tip plastic cement, Olfa hobby knife blades, and black and brown Gundam panel liners.

Included in the box are runners made of quality hard plastics that don't get stress marks easily, multiple sets of 1x2mm water slide decals for the eyes, and the build manual. The build itself was straightforward with clear 3D lined instructions. You start with the core/inner frame, but just like with the robomaid Yui kit you have to disassemble the head and forearms and replace them with the actual armored pieces. I simply skipped those parts of the core to save time. All pieces are snap-on or slide-in, but some smaller pieces such as the red pearl, thighs and sphinx's beard fall off easily during handling. You can be patient and keep reattaching those items or just glue them in place like I did.

Articulation is surprisingly nice. There are ball joints in the head, lower back, upper legs, shoulders, feet and hands. The knees are double jointed allowing for a full 180 bend. The elbows are basic hinge joints. Finally there are also swivel joints in the the upper arms and upper legs allowing for rotation on top of the ball joint movement.

In terms of accessories you get a floor and a backdrop, a throne, 3 weapons, wings for Esis which you can also fold up and attach to the throne, and a transformable sphinx/sarcophagus. You can also replace the spinx's head with the upper torso of Esis if that's your thing. The floor and backdrop can be reversed with one side being robo-egyptian themed and the other being the default style from the other Fiftyseven kits. All in all, I'd say this kit was definitely worth it despite it's small size. The robomaid Yui kit felt lackluster as it focused more on clothing options, where this Esis focuses more on aesthetics and accessories.

8/10, can't wait to see what robowaifu they release next.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91119909
>Is the color really this different? Or did we kinda get chinked this time?
It does look more golden-yellow in real life than the golden-orange from the product previews. But I don't mind it, the glossy plastic with some marbling still sells the gold effect it's going for.

>damn, i used a nail nipper and thats all for my yui lmao. How do i avoid damaging them when cutting? do i need any of these fancy things?
Quality nippers allow you to neatly remove parts from the runner (sheet of parts). Often these cuts will be barely visible, if visible at all. To achieve a perfect cut you want to cut each part twice. The first cut 2mm away from the part, the second flush to the part. This greatly reduces the risk of getting stress marks (ie plastic turning white) and nubs (remaining pieces of runner on part).

Hobby knives are mostly just nice to have to clean up cuts gone wrong or remove accidental nubs. Any cheap set will do, I just prefer Olfa blades as they are sharp as fuck and hold their edge.

Plastic cement is not required to build this kit. I just didn't had the patience to deal with the parts that repeatedly came off and already had it laying around from previous builds.

Panel liners are an easy way of adding depth and shadows to parts by tracing edges and grooves and then wiping off excess ink. The effect is pretty noticeable when you compare the pictures. Fineliners and pencils can achieve a similar effect but don't play nice with all plastics so do try it on a spare part or on the inside of a part.

In the end it's all up to you and how far you want to take things. I too once started with nail clippers and slowly purchased nicer tools and new techniques as I got more into model kits and started buying expensive kits. But if I had to recommend one item if you intend on building more kits, it would definitely be the nippers.

>Mine arrived but i'm waiting for the weekend so i can do it in peace, once again...
Enjoy your build anon!

Similarly, phthalates, which are often added to plastic products to increase their flexibility, have been linked to an increased risk of testicular cancer.

In addition to the cancer risks, Chinese plastic products are also known to contain heavy metals and other toxic substances that can harm the human body. These toxins can leach into food and drink, leading to serious health issues such as neurological damage and reproductive issues.

It is therefore highly recommended to avoid Chinese-made plastic products as much as possible, especially when it comes to items that come into direct contact with food and drink. Instead, opt for glass, stainless steel, or BPA-free plastic alternatives.
It is also important to recycle, reduce and reuse plastic products.

It is important to be aware of the potential health risks associated with Chinese plastic products and take steps to protect ourselves and our loved ones. To safeguard your health and reduce your risk of cancer, it is essential to avoid Chinese plastic products and opt for safer, more sustainable alternatives.

>>91172035

It is difficult to predict exactly when robots will be able to fully perform household tasks, as it depends on a number of factors, including advances in technology, cost, and regulatory issues. However, there are already some robots available on the market that can perform certain household tasks, such as vacuuming or mowing lawns.

One of the main difficulties towards the goal of household robots is the ability for the robot to navigate and understand the layout of a home. It also requires the ability to identify and interact with a wide variety of objects, such as furniture and household items. Additionally, household tasks often require dexterity and manipulation skills that are difficult to replicate in robots.

Another difficulty is creating a single robot that can perform a wide range of tasks effectively, rather than having a separate robot for each task.

Finally, the cost of development and production of these robots is currently high, which means they will not be affordable for most people.

In summary, while there are already some robots that can perform certain household tasks, there are still many challenges to overcome before robots will be able to perform all household tasks.

Welcome to /fat/ - Friendly Apple Thread

Goal of the thread: Treat yourself to something nice, be it a meal, a hot bath, or something else you'd enjoy doing.
Daily goals can be repeated. Remember to keep score, it can only go up!

>What is this thread for?
Getting better is hard, and sucks. A lot. It does not get easier doing it alone.
Share resources and experiences with combating depression, anxiety, personal issues, achieving or maintaining a healthy weight, etc.
>Why is this thread /lgbt/?
Struggles with mental and physical health are an indisputable part of /lgbt/ life, be it from dysphoria, social pressure, heartbreak, or just unfortunate lifestyle choices.
>Notes to consider:
Please be civil. Shame is your greatest enemy in fighting urges of self abuse (be it sh, drugs, or just self deprecation). Relapsing into bad and unhealthy habits is to be expected, the goal is to increase the average amount of time it takes between relapses. Any improvement is a victory no matter how small. Your worth and right to get better are non-negotiable. And most importantly:
WE ARE NOT THERAPISTS, WE DON'T REPLACE MEDICATION
>Note on advice
Generic advice won't necessarily help you in particular, but for those it does it is an essential foundation to build future progress on, not a miracle cure. Do not underestimate the effects subtle changes to your lifestyle can have. Try first, keep us posted on your progress, build from there.

ah well there's a little confusion here. i'm assuming despite your install being janky or whatever you're still using the normal up to date automatic1111 webui, so what you're looking for is this (picrel), luckily hires fix is a feature already built into the webui.

and yeah the UI surrounded it changed recently so there was some grumbling but it works fine. and btw there's a good comparison and little writeup about the benefits of the feature here https://github.com/AUTOMATIC1111/stable-diffusion-webui/wiki/Features#hires-fix

there isn't anything in the settings you need to mess with to enable and use the fix, and it should really be enabled whenever generating an image with a dimension >=960 or so, which is to say most of the time unless you're whipping out quick test renders

as far as good values to use for it, if you have the default latent upscaler selected (shown in the pic) a value of .6-.7 will work well

>>91174216
yea sounds like you're a little out of date, but the old one worked just as well but just didn't expose a couple extra config options

my recommendation is to leave firstpass height/width at '0' it'll automatically select good values for them, and the default denoising of .7 should be fine in most cases.

and the way it works is behind the scenes the hires fix will upscale your image from whatever base resolution it generated at (again, no real need to set this manually), and then automatically run an img2img on the upscaled result to basically use the base gen's composition as the basis for a higher resolution generation, which will cut down on the repeated heads/body parts/fleshpiles/repeated other bullshit, while being a higher quality generation than just upscaling would get you

yeah higher res = higher gen times unfortunately, and higher vram usage too. if your batch size is too high you might run into out of memory errors which'll display in the console window, in which case lower batch size or res

and i don't know your setup but if you haven't already you might also try enabling xformers by editing the webui-user.bat file command line options to read
>set COMMANDLINE_ARGS=--xformers

for many people this speeds things up and reduces vram usage, but from what i understand it isn't on by default because for certain cards it might not work well. this might also require a more up-to-date webui but i'm unsure about that

posts.com:
>>91174049
>someone said for AOM2 my denoise needs to be around 0.5
They sound like a brainlet, denoise shouldn't really differ based on model. Basically what denoise means (in the context of img2img or hires fix) is the degree to which the model is allowed to splash the paint around changing the picture when it's doing its thing changing the input picture's pixels. So, "hi res fix" is just shorthand for "generate me an image at a low res like 512x512 where SD is good at getting a nice scene composition, then img2img upscale it to a resolution like 1024x1024 where it has enough room to flesh out the details and make it beautiful". It's an inbuilt checkbox you can enable on the vanilla auto1111 txt2img tab and realistically should ALWAYS be used, you basically cannot make nice pictures without it, or if you are, you're doing it as a trick to demonstrate that it's possible.
>I'm told Hires Fix just moves some settings to the main tabs from the Settings tab
This sounds like the wording in the hiresfixjan23 rentry which captured a moment in time where hires fix got a slight update to its UI which moved some old important settings hidden in the settings tab to the front page, because everyone was missing them and accidentally generating garbage (mainly the choice of default upscaler prior to img2imging; if you don't understand what that means don't worry).
>which slider from Settings in the base A1111 gets moved to txt2img and renamed "denoise"
Denoise never got moved or renamed, it always appears after you hit the "hi res fix" checkbox on the txt2img tab. It should be set to around 0.3 if you're using a GAN upscaler (in the dropdown menu that appears!) such as lollypop or remacri or esr4x or whatever they're called which will get you an image very similar to the base resolution starting image, but needs to be more like 0.6 if you're using the upscaler named "Latent" which will get you more intricate detail if that's the style you want. AOM2 irrelevant.

>>91163517
From Brendan Eich's blog:

I was recruited to Netscape with the promise of “doing Scheme” in the browser. At least client engineering management including Tom Paquin, Michael Toy, and Rick Schell, along with some guy named Marc Andreessen, were convinced that Netscape should embed a programming language, in source form, in HTML. So it was hardly a case of me selling a “pointy-haired boss” — more the reverse.

Whether that language should be Scheme was an open question, but Scheme was the bait I went for in joining Netscape. Previously, at SGI, Nick Thompson had turned me on to SICP.

What was needed was a convincing proof of concept, AKA a demo. That, I delivered, and in too-short order it was a fait accompli.

Of course, by the time I joined Netscape,[...] the Oak language had been renamed Java, and Netscape was negotiating with Sun to include it in Navigator.

The big debate inside Netscape therefore became “why two languages? why not just Java?” The answer was that two languages were required to serve the two mostly-disjoint audiences in the programming ziggurat who most deserved dedicated programming languages: the component authors, who wrote in C++ or (we hoped) Java; and the “scripters”, amateur or pro, who would write code directly embedded in HTML.

Whether any existing language could be used, instead of inventing a new one, was also not something I decided. The diktat from upper engineering management was that the language must “look like Java”. That ruled out Perl, Python, and Tcl, along with Scheme.

I’m not proud, but I’m happy that I chose Scheme-ish first-class functions and Self-ish (albeit singular) prototypes as the main ingredients. The Java influences, especially y2k Date bugs but also the primitive vs. object distinction (e.g., string vs. String), were unfortunate.

How does DT 177X compare to 770?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91133359
Drop seems to have changed the pads out from the 1770, which made improvements in some areas but made it worse in others and neither seem to be worth the premium over the 770.

I think the real consideration is the 770 vs the 700, the latter has less sub-bass but the treble response is smoother in the sense that details in the cymbals and shit are less likely to become grating and the vocals a bit less sibilant. However I like that type of treble extension in a lot of music and for non-music so it's not something I hold against the 770. Actually it's a bit refreshing because it's normal for manufacturers to play it too safe in that area, e.g. the HD 600, since it decreases the likelihood of returns. Pad wear typically reduces it further so from a consumer perspective that isn't great and I think it's better to have too much than too little. You can always tame it by using EQ or adding a piece of paper towel on the back side of the pads.

It is a very written and configured distro. Their package manager "apk" is the fastest out there right now.

The biggest issue is lack of documentation. The wiki is very scatterbrain.

I tried it out a year ago and ran into too many pain points (fonts not rendering, bad video playback, no automounting usb devices) but was a noob then.

Understanding linux in-depth and the packages I like to go help now whenever I run alpine. I run alpine whenever I want a binary based distro and dont want to deal with compiling my whole system with KISS or Gentoo.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91156619
maybe you don't need 4000 devs to maintain a fucking message board website. maybe this is the question that no one is even asking.

why the fuck does twitter, a website that lets you post fucking text, possibly need a microservice architecture? microservices are supposed to give modularity at the cost of increased development time and a more complicated network stack/topology. microservices are really only justifiable in products that have 1000s of crazy features, connect a bunch of different machines, deal with huge amounts of a variety of different types of data and situations.

digital telescope networks, university backends that need to sync up with student loan offices/government agencies across the world, etc etc etc. these are the types of systems that benefit from microservices, because the requirements and the parameters of the systems are constantly in flux: the added cost of development is offset by the modularity in systems where you can't guarantee that things will be functioning the same way in a year.

twitter is a website where people send pictures and text to each other. it doesn't need 4000 developers and it certainly doesn't need microservices.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>they don't know
The CPU is dead. Long since as a matter of fact. What we have in modern chips called SoCs or APUs for AMD are heterogeneous processing units. We have multiple types of CPU cores, GPU cores, dedicated media accelerators, dedicated AI/ML accelerators.
All of these IPs are needed to remain relevant on the bleeding edge of the market, and all of these things require immense R&D expenditure.
Intel has had IGPs forever, longer than AMD, but intel considered them a true bare minimum display output, not something actually useful to the average user. That is no longer the case. The IGP is an integral part of the system, and in the future IGP performance will only matter more and more. For intel their discrete graphics cards are a way to increase TAM and recoup R&D expenditure to keep their graphics IP relevant on the bleeding edge.

In a few years when everything you currently own is utterly irrelevant you will understand.

>>91093987
> how much of a meme are gaming mousepads
They're not. There are cloth pads, and then there are Artisan cloth pads (jp company that makes cloth pads with similar static friction as hard plastics). Then there are hard plastics & metals - these tend to be lower friction than cloth but are much less durable. As in, the surface texture will wear, fucking with your aim,
then you'll have to replace them once every 1-2 years depending on how sweaty a gamer you are. And finally there's glass, which does away with hard plastic's limitations but wears your mouse skates much faster.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>91116958
>Endgame gear XM1r
I suppose I can give my review.
It's a decent mouse, but the Kailh switches are maybe not the absolute best for action rts games. It has click detection and scroll issues that you need to update the firmware in order to fix. This firmware is hosted on a discord server, last time I checked... The latest version seems to have fixed all problems for me however.
Other than that weight's good, cable's good, no big issues have come up. One minor issue that did happen to me is that there's space enough for a dirt flake to get into the mouse and onto the switch. Then you'll have to disassemble the mouse to clean it up. That's done easily enough, and I may have been very unlucky to have it happen in the first place, but it was super annoying until I figured it out.
I would say the mouse is decent, but kinda mediocre, except there's the very nice and light middle click that's perfect if you play games like Dota 2 with hold-middle-to-pan. That makes it extremely worth to try using if you've converted to that pan method.

Atompalm is similar in these regards and is much cheaper than Zaunkoenig (but Zaunkoenig is made of carbon fiber, making it the lightest mouse in existence)

Also both are 8000hz with actual good sensors and processors/firmware.

TL:DR I need recommendations for a budget vertical mouse that isn't shit (build quality, won't die young, has a decent sensor for workstation stuff and non-precision-dependent games) and a palm grip gaming mouse that also isn't shit (the usual stuff but also reasonable quality control and no fucking planned obsolescence switches).
