posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>91088422
There are two types of resistance. Inertia and friction. Dynamic friction is good, because like you said, you can control the amount of movement with amount of effort. Inertia is very bad, it significantly slows the process of moving the cursor from point A to point B because of the time needed to accelerate and deaccelerate again, which also makes it prone to overshooting. With a light mouse you can just snap the cursor to desired location without any acceleration time and overshoots.
It's especially important for tracking aim that you can update to match enemy trajectory as soon as possible. Moving enemy stops? On light mouse: Good, just stop moving the mouse. On heavy mouse your aim continues to move along the wrong path and it takes extra time to correct the course towards where the enemy is actually going.
As a bonus, light mouse makes it trivial to quickly flick the camera around to scan the area for increased game awareness.

Most of these heavymousefags are probably also using too high sensitivity from the old times. Higher sensitivity technically helps at minimizing the time needed to aim from A to B and I personally use much higher sensitivity than esportsfags, but it also makes your aim very imprecise. When you switch to a light mouse and reduce sensitivity, you get similar feeling result but without the inertia that objectively fucks up your maximum possible reaction speed. Tracking with a light mouse feels like aimbot compared to those old trucker mice.

>>91171625
>how much longer till video generation
meta has 1 (gif length) and google has 2 (gif length and vid length) txt2vid currently at the level txt2img processing was at about 18 months ago give or take, sorta dall-e 1 stuff, i think it'll be a bit longer to hit good quality for vids tho due to clunkiness of accessing and using large datasets of video. give it a year or two to hit current level (which, again, isn't really bulk commercial ready but is hobbyist/artisan ready so give it a year on top too). Ignore people using img2img to do frame by frame, it's not viable as a technique for vids.
>how much longer till hand, feet and other fine details are fixed with minimal need for post processing
less than a year; in fact i'd say closed source models for image gen probably do this fine already such as google's Imagen which is many times larger and more powerful than SD, hell even midjourney does a good job.
>could this by dynamically generated in a VR sandbox like Virtamate via plugins
images? sure. already people made some CYOA stuff which is the obvious application, AI Dungeon with imgs. Would rely on clever working around the limitations. And not a 3D model.
>could this be linked to Replika and other similar relationship AIs via plugins
trivial. see what CAI does with images turned on for a really dogshit example
>if the above are both true, what would be the main roadblocks of there finally being a dynamically generated AI girlfriend that is interactable both in text and visual form
the strongest current models are behind paywalls held by companies either w/ a reputation to protect from porn, worried about paypal cracking down on porn, or are anti-porn themselves. weaker models are open. this dynamic will continue so there will always be a split between people who want the strongest-but-sorta-filtered AI, or want the free open source AI for w/e.
>costs to support client base of 100,000
idk

>>91171625
>>91171700 here
more generally, look at AIDungeon's history (txt), NovelAI (some bad txt, great img and unfiltered), MidJourney (great img, paywalled/closed/filtered), CharacterAI (good chat txt, bad img tacked on) and Pygmalion (open source CAI, nice demonstration of the limitations vs benefits of that), and ofc SD and i suppose DALLE2/GPT3/ChatGPT, for examples of who's failed and why vs who's successful, depending on their goals being money or just prestige/tech advancement/investment. Note that CAI is more research than commercial despite how it looks. Overall I would say "I could get a loan of $500k with promises of 10x that or more from backers if the initial thing looks promising" is kind of a bare minimum and in this space likely you still get crushed, there is a feeding frenzy on right now and you'll be right there up against megacap tech pouring tens of billions into the most cutting edge teams on the planet so really you need to be leveraging a genuinely clever and novel way of using the API of a powerful system in a profitable way to corner the market on it in a way that somebody else having a more powerful model than you won't simply undercut you by default

>>91171625
The big thing is that we aren't at multimodality yet. Not even Google is doing that.

"Video" in your mind is audio + motion. Motion is coming this year and I'd imagine in a full year or two it will be as good as image is now(really good). But having that hooked up in with believable audio is another step above that, it's a big challenge. There are absolutely massive investments made into this technology and we'll see legit full features in a few years, but your babby $500k is not going to interest the codemonkeys working on this stuff in regards to the bleeding edge. Your best bet is to just wait it out and try to capitalize on this tech some months after it comes out, like how Lensa AI got rich off img2img which made all of us feel a bit silly.

This error is usually caused by an incompatibility between the architecture of the executable file and the architecture of the library it is linking to. This can happen if the executable is compiled for a different CPU architecture than the library. To resolve this issue, you will need to recompile the executable for the same architecture as the library, or find a library with the same architecture as the executable.

bingo
current bot definition meta is absolutely quality over quantity
using W++ formatting for character traits, and good descriptive example chats

i'm no expert, so some of this may be factually inaccurate:
every 4 characters is a 'token', and you get 2048 tokens total in the current model. that's split between your bot definition and the chat log. so try keep your bot definition around 900 tokens max, then it has enough memory for around 15 messages in the chat log

posts.com:
>>91163222
>AOSP is basically useless without some equivalent of Play Services
that's not the main issue with Android. Play Services are controlled by Google so it's expected that it doesn't work with open source forks, but the real issue is that most of the vendor blobs are also closed source. Like, take ISM blobs for example - the LineageOS devs haven't been able to reverse engineer Korea OEM's IMS software so their devices are essentially usable on LineageOS (hence, any other custom ROM, or Ubuntu Touch/Sailfish).
The lack of standardization of these components is a very big issue.
Android is basically proprietary garbage for phones; only niche embedded devices running Android can be called open source.
>better to give root access on my device to a company that makes money selling overpriced hardware rather than an ad company
You don't have to choose either. Pixels and Oneplus phones have solid custom ROM devs. You can easily use signature spoofed lineageOS with microG services to have 90-95% Google Play functionality without the tracking.

>Does upgrading the battery void the warranty
If you bought the phone from Apple and have an AppleCare warranty, I believe so. If you bought it used and/or the warranty is expired then no harm done.
>or activate some apple thing that fucks your phone?
If anything it's the opposite. From my experience Apple's alleged throttling of older devices has nothing to do with the devices age, but instead the health of the battery. You can view this in the settings app and it will even tell you if the battery supports normal operation. So, swapping an old/drained battery for a new one should FIX the issue.
Disclaimer, I haven't done any research to back that up, but I have personal experience. My 2016 SE was slow as shit, replaced the battery, and after one year it still works great. Obviously it can be a little sluggish running iOS 15 on a 7 year old device but it's perfectly usable.
